pages.title: exploring the file system
pages.text:
exploring the file system
new execs in this lesson: cd + touch + man + rm
length: 30-40 mins
what is a file system?

a collection of files and directories
directories can only hold files or other directories
Finder is probably how you're most familiar to getting around a file system
show example with finder


in the terminal, we have to use commands in order to navigate the file system
in this lesson we'll learn how to do this!
open your terminal!

execute
ls .
see the dirs and files of your current dir
execute
cd Documents

cd stands for "change directory"
english translation: "change directory to" "Documents"

execute
ls .

see the dirs and files of Documents
compare to Finder

execute
cd ../

english translation: "change directory to" "parent directory"
family relationships are used to describe file systems:
parent, child, sibling
show example of each relationship in Finder


now we're in the same dir that we started

execute
ls .
now we see that these are the same files and dirs that we had when we began
creating and deleting files

execute touch hello.txt
english translation: "create a file" "called hello.txt" 

was hello.txt was really created?
how can we check?

    execute ls .
    view in finder
    


execute
rm hello.txt
english translation: "ReMove" "hello.txt"
so...how can we make sure this file was deleted?
same as before!


command history

you can press the "up arrow" key to cycle back through your history of executed commads
use "down arrow" to cycle forward

errors are your friend

cycle through your history and get to the command rm hello.txt
execute it
the result is error: execute rm: foo.txt: No such file or directory
we were telling the terminal to delete a file that doesnt exist, so the terminal let us know that this file doesnt exist

creating directories

execute ls .
we're going to create a new directory, so we want to make sure that it doesnt exist yet in our file system


execute mkdir hello
english translation: "create a directory" "called 'hello'"



command history
use terminal history ("up arrow") to get to ls . and execute it
make sure that the hello dir is there
attempt to delete a directory
execute rm hello

english translation: "remove" "hello">
rm: hello/: is a directory
what do we do...?

execute
man <exec>

english translation: "show me the MANual for" "any executable"
lets use man to find out if we can use rm to delete dirs
execute man rm
we're in a file-read mode!
this used to freak me out! i didnt know how to get out of it or what it was!
interface:
"space bar" => "scroll down"
"b" =>    "scroll up"
"q" =>  "exit read mode"


find entry for -d
press q (exit file-read)



execute
rm -d hello
execitable  option          argument
"remove"    "a directory"   "hello"

options are always specified with a -
we should have succeeded this time in deleting hello
check using ls .

FUN FACT

dont do this!
sudo rm -rf .
if you do this at the top-level directory of a computer, it will delete EVERYTHING

pages.title: Our First Commands
pages.text:
Our First Commands
new executables: open + ls
length: 10-15 mins
our first command: open

open terminal
type open .
press "enter"

we just executed our first command!
in other words, you typed something into your terminal and pressed "enter"
think of commands as sentences for computers
dissecting open .



language
sentence




bash
open .


english
"open with Finder"  "this directory"


generalized
"take this action" "onto this"


linguistic
"verb" "prepositional phrase"


computer science
"executable" "argument"



what is a "command"?

we can perform actions in a terminal by "executing commands"

a command is composed of three parts:

executable
arguments
options


we'll only deal with executables and arguments for now

the parts of a command are separated by spaces, just like in written english


the executable
open .

the first part of any command is the executable
for this command, the executable is open
think of executables as the verbs of the CLI
an executable is the action that we want to occur

the argument
open .

in this command, the . is called an argument
think of arguments as the nouns of the CLI
an argument describes what we want to act upon with our executable (aka verb)



our second command: ls

execute ls .
L i S t
compare the terminal output with the Finder dir
translation to english: "list the contents of" "this directory"
now we've seen two different commands use . as an argument, open and ls

pages.title: Setting up our machines
pages.text:
Setting up our machines
length: 10-15 mins
challenge!

use the terminal to create the following file: ./Code/learn2code/01/index.html
add some text to it
display this page in a web browser

steps to create the file

mkdir Code
this is where all code you'll write on your computer goes


cd Code
mkdir learn2code
this is where all code you'll write during these sessions goes


cd learn2code
mkdir project-01
this is where all code for our first project will go


cd project-01
touch index.html 

ways to display an html file in a browser

drag the file into the browser app in the dock
through the terminal...
navigate to the dir where index.html lives
execute python2.7 -m SimpleHTTPServer 3000
navigate to localhost:3000 in the browser

pages.title: What is the terminal and why do we need it?
pages.text:
What is the terminal and why do we need it?
length: 10-15 mins
all technology has an interface
our interaction with macs mainly depends on these three components:

    keyboards
    mice
    screen
    


compare to household object(s)

microwave
LED display, buttons, dials, etc


smartphone
touchscreen, buttons, microphone


ask students

there are two ways to interfact with our macs

Graphic User Interface

keyboard, screen, mouse simultaneously
graphic-based interface
layered windows
clicking on the screen makes stuff happen




Command Line Interface

only keyboard and screen
text-based interface
clicking on the screen DOES NOT make stuff happen





each interface is better suited for different tasks

GUI

great for visual content
photos
videos
forms
use fb page as example


learning curve is much smaller than the CLI


CLI

no input restrictions
i can surf the web, delete my hard drive, edit text
